description: Identifying reasoning errors where a person makes a flawed logical conclusion. Questions ask which sentence shows the mistake they have made.

concepts.name: Identifying the Reasoning Error
concepts.description: Finding which specific step or conclusion in a person's reasoning contains the logical mistake
common_misconceptions: Identifying a false statement rather than the flawed reasoning
Not distinguishing between incorrect facts and invalid logic
Missing where the error actually occurs in the chain
question_patterns: [Person] reasons as follows: [chain of reasoning]. Which sentence shows their mistake?
At which step does [person]'s reasoning go wrong?
example_stems: Tom thinks: All dogs bark. My pet barks. So my pet is a dog. Where is Tom's error?
Sara reasons: It's cloudy, so it will rain. It will rain, so I need an umbrella. It won't rain tomorrow. Where does Sara's reasoning fail?

concepts.name: False Cause Error
concepts.description: Recognizing when someone incorrectly assumes one thing caused another
common_misconceptions: Accepting temporal sequence as proof of causation
question_patterns: [Person] concludes that X caused Y. Which statement shows the flaw?
example_stems: I wore my lucky socks and won the game. The socks caused my win. What's the error?
After the new policy, sales increased. The policy improved sales. Where's the mistake?

concepts.name: Hasty Generalization
concepts.description: Recognizing when someone draws a broad conclusion from too few examples
common_misconceptions: Accepting personal experience as universal truth
Missing the jump from specific to general
question_patterns: [Person] concludes that all X are Y. Where is the error?
What's wrong with generalizing from this example?
example_stems: I met two rude people from that city. Everyone there must be rude. What's the flaw?
My brother is tall. All boys must be tall. Where's the error in reasoning?

concepts.name: Affirming the Consequent
concepts.description: Recognizing the error of concluding 'If A then B' means 'If B then A'
common_misconceptions: Thinking the converse is always true
question_patterns: [Person] reasons: If A then B. B is true. So A must be true. What's the error?
Where does reversing the conditional go wrong?
example_stems: If it rains, the ground is wet. The ground is wet. So it rained. What's the mistake?
All doctors study medicine. Kim studies medicine. So Kim is a doctor. Where's the flaw?

concepts.name: False Dichotomy
concepts.description: Recognizing when someone presents only two options when more exist
common_misconceptions: Not considering middle ground or alternatives
question_patterns: [Person] says it must be X or Y. What's wrong with this reasoning?
Why is limiting to these two options a mistake?
example_stems: You're either with us or against us. Why is this reasoning flawed?
Either we cancel the trip or go bankrupt. What option is being ignored?

concepts.name: Circular Reasoning
concepts.description: Recognizing when the conclusion is assumed in the premise
common_misconceptions: Not noticing when the argument assumes its conclusion
question_patterns: [Person]'s argument assumes what it tries to prove. Which part shows this?
Where is the circular reasoning in this argument?
example_stems: This book is popular because everyone reads it. Everyone reads it because it's popular. What's the flaw?
Exercise is healthy because healthy people exercise. Where's the circular reasoning?
